title: Time to pay up? Reparations and global development challenges
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Time to pay up? Reparations and global development challenges," seeks to study the emerging calls for reparations in global development contexts. The project, titled REPAIR, will focus on comparing reparations for various global challenges such as infectious disease outbreaks, climate change, minority rights violations, and toxic environments. 

The main objectives of this study include comparing how reparations payments are established, implemented, and received in addressing these development challenges, as well as understanding the economic, moral, and political perspectives of these payments. Additionally, the project aims to identify the type of wealth transfer that reparations constitute and explore the "reparative aspects" of economic life.

This project stands out as the first comparative social-science study of reparations in the field of development. It broadens the comparative frame of reparations study and utilizes novel theory and methods from economic anthropology to investigate reparations as a form of wealth transfer. By focusing on the "reparative aspects" of economic activity, this study will provide valuable insights into the role of reparations in addressing global development challenges.
